messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 62 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: A Refutation of the Pach-Tardos Conjecture for 0–1 MatricesS. Pettie is supported by NSF Grant CCF-2221980. G. Tardos is supported by the National Research, Development and Innovation Office projects K-132696 and SNN-135643 and by the ERC Advanced Grants “ERMiD” and “GeoScape.”

Paper Abstract: Abstract The theory of forbidden 0–1 matrices generalizes Turán-style (bipartite) subgraph avoidance, Davenport-Schinzel theory, and Zarankiewicz-type problems, and has been influential in many areas, such as discrete and computational geometry, the analysis of self-adjusting data structures, and the development of the graph parameter twin width. The foremost open problems in this area is to resolve the Pach-Tardos conjecture from 2005, which states that if a forbidden pattern P∈{0,1}k×l𝑃superscript01𝑘𝑙P\in\{0,1\}^{k\times l} is the bipartite incidence matrix of an acyclic graph (forest), then Ex⁡(P,n)=O​(n​logCP⁡n)Ex𝑃𝑛𝑂𝑛superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑃𝑛\operatorname{Ex}(P,n)=O(n\log^{C_{P}}n), where CPsubscript𝐶𝑃C_{P} is a constant depending only on P𝑃P. This conjecture has been confirmed on many small patterns, specifically all P𝑃P with weight at most 5, and all but two with weight 6. The main result of this paper is a clean refutation of the Pach-Tardos conjecture. Specifically, we prove that Ex⁡(S0,n),Ex⁡(S1,n)≥n​2Ω​(log⁡n)Exsubscript𝑆0𝑛Exsubscript𝑆1𝑛𝑛superscript2Ω𝑛\operatorname{Ex}(S_{0},n),\operatorname{Ex}(S_{1},n)\geq n2^{\Omega(\sqrt{\log n})}, where S0,S1subscript𝑆0subscript𝑆1S_{0},S_{1} are the outstanding weight-6 patterns. S0subscript𝑆0\displaystyle S_{0} =(∙∙∙∙∙∙),absent∙missing-subexpression∙missing-subexpression∙missing-subexpressionmissing-subexpression∙missing-subexpression∙missing-subexpression∙\displaystyle=\left(\begin{array}[]{cccc}\bullet&&\bullet&\\ \bullet&&&\bullet\\ &\bullet&&\bullet\end{array}\right), S1subscript𝑆1\displaystyle S_{1} =(∙∙∙∙∙∙),absent∙missing-subexpressionmissing-subexpression∙∙missing-subexpression∙missing-subexpressionmissing-subexpression∙missing-subexpression∙\displaystyle=\left(\begin{array}[]{cccc}\bullet&&&\bullet\\ \bullet&&\bullet&\\ &\bullet&&\bullet\end{array}\right), Ptsubscript𝑃𝑡\displaystyle P_{t} =(∙⏞t+1 alternating 1s∙∙∙∙∙⋯∙).\displaystyle=\left(\begin{array}[]{ccccccc}\bullet&\makebox[0.0pt][l]{$\raisebox{11.38109pt}[0.0pt][0.0pt]{$\overbrace{\hskip 95.3169pt}^{\text{$t+1$ alternating 1s}}$}$}\bullet&&\bullet&&&\bullet\\ \bullet&&\bullet&&\raisebox{6.82864pt}[0.0pt][0.0pt]{$\cdots$}&\bullet&\end{array}\right). We also prove sharp bounds on the entire class of alternating patterns (Pt)subscript𝑃𝑡(P_{t}), specifically that for every t≥2𝑡2t\geq 2, Ex⁡(Pt,n)=Θ​(n​(log⁡n/log⁡log⁡n)t)Exsubscript𝑃𝑡𝑛Θ𝑛superscript𝑛𝑛𝑡\operatorname{Ex}(P_{t},n)=\Theta(n(\log n/\log\log n)^{t}). This is the first proof of an asymptotically sharp bound that is ω​(n​log⁡n)𝜔𝑛𝑛\omega(n\log n).

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 62 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 62"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "New graph decompositions and combinatorial boolean matrix multiplication algorithms",
        "On sets of integers which contain no three terms in arithmetic progression",
        "An extremal problem on sparse 0–1 matrices",
        "Twin-width II: small classes",
        "Twin-width I: tractable FO model checking",
        "Cycles of even length in graphs",
        "The Kelley–Meka bounds for sets free of three-term arithmetic progressions",
        "Improved pattern-avoidance bounds for greedy BSTs via matrix decomposition",
        "Greedy is an almost optimal deque",
        "Pattern-avoiding access in binary search trees",
        "On constants in the Füredi-Hajnal and the Stanley-Wilf conjecture",
        "Better upper bounds on the Füredi-Hajnal limits of permutations",
        "Sorting pattern-avoiding permutations via 0-1 matrices forbidding product patterns",
        "On the structure of linear graphs",
        "A limit theorem in graph theory",
        "Davenport-Schinzel theory of matrices",
        "Extremal problems for convex geometric hypergraphs and ordered hypergraphs",
        "Ordered and convex geometric trees with linear extremal function",
        "Stanley-Wilf limits are typically exponential, 2013.",
        "The history of degenerate (bipartite) extremal graph problems",
        "Linear bound on extremal functions of some forbidden patterns in 0–1 matrices",
        "The maximum number of unit distances in a convex n𝑛n-gon",
        "Extremal functions of forbidden double permutation matrices",
        "Bounds on extremal functions of forbidden patterns",
        "Forbidden formations in multidimensional 0–1 matrices",
        "On the Turán number of some ordered even cycles",
        "Finding small patterns in permutations in linear time",
        "Turán problems for edge-ordered graphs",
        "Extremal functions of forbidden multidimensional matrices",
        "Sharper bounds and structural results for minimally nonlinear 0-1 matrices",
        "Nonlinearity of Davenport-Schinzel sequences and of generalized path compression schemes",
        "Tight general bounds for the extremal numbers of 0–1 matrices, 2024.",
        "On linear forbidden submatrices",
        "A general upper bound in extremal theory of sequences",
        "The Füredi-Hajnal conjecture implies the Stanley-Wilf conjecture",
        "Generalized Davenport-Schinzel sequences: results, problems, and applications",
        "Strong bounds for 3-progressions",
        "A characterization of edge-ordered graphs with almost linear extremal functions",
        "On edge-ordered graphs with linear extremal functions",
        "On the Turán number of ordered forests",
        "Generalized Davenport-Schinzel sequences",
        "L1subscript𝐿1{L}_{1} shortest paths among polygonal obstacles in the plane",
        "Excluded permutation matrices and the Stanley-Wilf conjecture",
        "Bipartite Turán problems for ordered graphs",
        "Improved bounds and new techniques for Davenport-Schinzel sequences and their generalizations",
        "Splay trees, Davenport-Schinzel sequences, and the deque conjecture",
        "Applications of forbidden 0–1 matrices to search tree- and path compression-based data structures",
        "Degrees of nonlinearity in forbidden 0–1 matrix problems",
        "Generalized Davenport-Schinzel sequences and their 0–1 matrix counterparts",
        "On the structure and composition of forbidden sequences, with geometric applications",
        "Sharp bounds on Davenport-Schinzel sequences of every order",
        "Three generalizations of Davenport-Schinzel sequences",
        "On vertical visibility in arrangements of segments and the queue size in the Bentley-Ottmann line sweeping algorithm",
        "New bounds on extremal numbers in acyclic ordered graphs",
        "Forbidden paths and cycles in ordered graphs and matrices",
        "On the extremal functions of acyclic forbidden 0-1 matrices",
        "Davenport-Schinzel Sequences and their Geometric Applications",
        "A tournament approach to pattern avoiding matrices",
        "On 0–1 matrices and small excluded submatrices",
        "On an extremal problem in graph theory",
        "Lower bounds on Davenport-Schinzel sequences via rectangular Zarankiewicz matrices",
        "Planar realizations of nonlinear Davenport-Schinzel sequences by segments"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 62 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in A Refutation of the Pach-Tardos Conjecture for 0–1 MatricesS. Pettie is supported by NSF Grant CCF-2221980. G. Tardos is supported by the National Research, Development and Innovation Office projects K-132696 and SNN-135643 and by the ERC Advanced Grants “ERMiD” and “GeoScape.”, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
